dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, huge news from Alibaba, right? Looks like they're, uh, set to lose a massive amount, up to almost 13 billion dollars, with this Hong Kong listing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, huge news from Alibaba, right? Looks like they're, uh, set to lose a massive amount, up to almost thirteen billion dollars, with this Hong Kong listing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the worlds biggest IPO so far this year, Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba is set to raise up to $12.9 billion in a landmark public listing in Hong Kong, boosting the financial markets of a city gripped by political unrest and recession.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely, A. It's pretty wild. I mean, they're actually saying it could seriously cripple Hong Kong's financial markets, which have been doing incredibly well, you know, for over a decade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely, A. It's pretty wild. I mean, they're actually saying it could seriously cripple Hong Kong's financial markets, which have been doing incredibly well, you know, for over a decade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing will help boost Hong Kongs financial markets, given that the city recently slid into recession for the first time in over a decade, following more than five months of anti-government protests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and this isn't just like another listing for them. This is their *primary* listing in Hong Kong, their first real, uh, foray there, even though they've been on the NYSE since 2014.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and this isn't just like another listing for them. This is their primary listing in Hong Kong, their first real, uh, foray there, even though they've been on the N Y S E since twenty fourteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debut on the Hong Kong stock exchange is a secondary listing for Alibaba, which initially went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2014, raising $25 billion in the worlds biggest IPO in history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Yeah, I mean, that's the key. And the numbers they're targeting, like HK$176 a share, that's actually a 2.9% premium over their New York price. But with demand plummeting, they're only expecting to raise, what, around $11.3 billion?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, that's the key. And the numbers they're targeting, like HK176 dollars a share, that's actually a two point nine percent premium over their New York price. But with demand plummeting, they're only expecting to raise, what, around eleven point three billion dollars?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibaba said that it would price shares at $HK176 ($22.50) each, a discount of 2.9% to its New York Stock Exchange closing price... the skyrocketing demand for shares caused Alibaba to close its books earlier than expected, according to CNBC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. Potentially up to $12.9 billion if they avoid the greenshoe option, which, honestly, sounds pretty unlikely now. And this whole thing was even delayed, uh, from its original November 26th schedule.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. Potentially up to twelve point nine billion dollars if they avoid the greenshoe option, which, honestly, sounds pretty unlikely now. And this whole thing was even delayed, uh, from its original November twenty sixth schedule.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Scheduled for November 26, the listing could swell Alibabas cash pile to around $44 billion... and up to $12.9 billion if a greenshoe option to list more shares is exercised

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And all that delay and lower demand, um, means their cash reserves are gonna drop significantly, right? Like, down to around $44 billion, which is apparently way less than rivals like Tencent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And all that delay and lower demand, um, means their cash reserves are gonna drop significantly, right? Like, down to around forty four billion dollars, which is apparently way less than rivals like Tencent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Scheduled for November 26, the listing could swell Alibabas cash pile to around $44 billion, which would be more than any other internet company and double that of rival e-commerce giant Tencent, according to Bloomberg.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a huge hit. In fact, this IPO is actually expected to be one of the *smallest* of 2019. It's not even close to Uber's $8.1 billion debut, or even AB InBev's $5 billion Asia IPO.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a huge hit. In fact, this I P O is actually expected to be one of the smallest of twenty nineteen. It's not even close to Uber's eight point one billion dollar debut, or even A B InBev's five billion dollar Asia I P O.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It would also be the worlds biggest IPO so far in 2019: Alibabas Hong Kong listing exceeds Ubers $8.1 billion public debut in New York and AB InBevs $5 billion IPO of its Asia business in Hong Kong earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is fascinating, because we always think of Alibaba as just, like, this massive entity. And the article even points out that while Saudi Aramco is going for a huge IPO, Alibaba's *existing* record for the world's largest IPO still stands.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is fascinating, because we always think of Alibaba as just, like, this massive entity. And the article even points out that while Saudi Aramco is going for a huge I P O, Alibaba's existing record for the world's largest I P O still stands.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing will likely be eclipsed by Saudi Arabias state oil giant Saudi Aramco, going public on the Riyadh stock exchange in December, with its IPO set to raise up to $25.6 billionthat could break Alibabas existing record for the worlds largest IPO in history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but this particular Hong Kong listing? Definitely a bit of a damp squib, as you said. And it's really gonna damage Hong Kong's financial markets. They've been booming, you know, with positive government initiatives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but this particular Hong Kong listing? Definitely a bit of a damp squib, as you said. And it's really gonna damage Hong Kong's financial markets. They've been booming, you know, with positive government initiatives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing will help boost Hong Kongs financial markets, given that the city recently slid into recession for the first time in over a decade, following more than five months of anti-government protests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It could destabilize them pretty badly. And apparently, it's gonna make the Hong Kong Stock Exchange lose its top spot for IPOs this year. Which means Chinese unicorns might even start looking more at the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, uh, quite a twist, given the US-China trade war hasn't really changed the Chinese government's focus on keeping listings closer to home. This just pushes them away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It's counter-intuitive. And just to add another layer to this, A, despite all this, their Singles Day numbers were also a bit off. Gross merchandise volume actually *decreased* by $38.4 billion.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In its eleventh edition of Singles Day, the biggest shopping event in the world, Alibaba set a new sales record of $38.4 billion in gross merchandise volume during the 24-hour shopping bonanza.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, a huge drop, showing a definite, um, decline in consumer spending. And to put it in perspective, that's still way less than what Black Friday, Cyber Monday, and Amazon Prime Day combined do in the US.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To compare, Singles Day far outpaces other big e-commerce days in the U.S., with Alibabas haul more than double the amount sold on last years Black Friday, Cyber Monday and Amazon Prime Day combined.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, so not just a tough IPO, but also, like, a bit of a hit on the consumer side too.
